contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel worshiping many idols as being like a woman having sex with many men. Alternate translation: "You have given your love and trust to idols the way a prostitute gives her body to men who are not her husband" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: You have lived as a prostitute who has many lovers

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of his people being eager to worship any idol as being like someone in the wilderness waiting for anyone to come along so he could rob them. Alternate translation: "like an Arab in the wilderness waiting for people he might rob" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as an Arab in the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks as of Israel worshiping idols as if she were a woman having sex with many men. Alternate translation: (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: she has acted like a prostitute

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel as if Israel were his son. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I want to treat you as my son

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Israel being unfaithful to him as if she were an unfaithful wife. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: But like a woman faithless to her husband, you have betrayed me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of becoming extremely angry as if his anger were fire. Alternate translation: "my anger will burn like a fire and no one will be able to stop it" or "I will be extremely angry, and no one will be able to stop me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: my fury will break out like fire, and burn with no one to quench it

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "he" refers to the enemy king and his army. The great size of the army is spoken of as if they were giant storm clouds. Alternate translation: "See, great armies like giant clouds are gathering to attack" or "See, great armies are gathering to attack" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: See, he is attacking like clouds

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemies' chariots are spoken of as if they were like a storm. Storms can be noisy, destructive, and fast-moving. Alternate translation: "the roar of their chariots coming is like a fierce storm" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: his chariots are like a storm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Carefully guarding a city to keep people from going in and out is spoken of as if they are carefully watching a field to keep people from stealing from it. Alternate translation: "they will guard Jerusalem carefully like watchmen who carefully guard a cultivated field" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They will be like the watchmen of a cultivated field against her all around

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile is used to show how greatly distressed Judah will be. Alternate translation: "severe distress as in the pain and suffering a woman has while giving birth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: distress as in the birth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of his message as if it were a fire, and of his people as if they were wood. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: It will be like a fire, and this people will be like wood

contextId.occurrenceNote: An open tomb is one that is prepared to have many dead bodies put in it. The enemy army will kill many people. Alternate translation: "That nation's army will use their arrows and kill many people" or "Because of the arrows of its army, many people will die and be buried" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Its quiver is like an open tomb

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of wicked people wanting to harm someone as if they were waiting to capture birds. Alternate translation: "Like someone hiding and waiting to capture birds" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They watch as someone crouches to capture birds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "deceit" represents the things that were taken by deceit. Alternate translation: Like a cage full of birds that a hunter has caught, wicked people's houses are full of things that they have taken by deceiving people (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Like a cage full of birds, their houses are full of deceit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "this city keeps producing wickedness" represents people in the city continuing to do wicked things. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As a well pours out fresh water, so this city keeps producing wickedness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The loud noise that the soldiers make is compared to the loud noise of the ocean. Alternate translation: "The sound that they make is very loud, like the sound of the ocean" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Their sound is like the sea roar

contextId.occurrenceNote: The anguish that they feel because the enemy coming to attack them is compared to the anguish that a woman feels when she is about to give birth to a baby. Alternate translation: "like a woman who is about to give birth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a woman giving birth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah compares the people's great sadness to the sadness that a mother feels if her only son dies. Alternate translation: "mourn with painful sobs as you would if your only son died" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: mourn with painful sobs as for an only son

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares Jeremiah testing his people to a person who tests metal to see how good it is. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: one who tests my people like one would test metal

contextId.occurrenceNote: The bones are compared to dung on the ground both to emphasize that they will be disgusting and because they will not be buried. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They will be like dung on the surface of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The eagerness of the people to follow their own evil way is compared to the eagerness of a war horse running toward a battle. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a stallion rushing toward battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes the great number of people who will die, by comparing their bodies to dung that falls in the fields. Alternate translation: "dead bodies will drop everywhere like animal dung falls all over the fields" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: corpses of men will fall like dung in the fields

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes the great number of people who will die, by comparing their bodies to cut stalks of grain. Alternate translation: "like stalks of grain fall everywhere after the farmers cut them down" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like grain stalks after the reapers

contextId.occurrenceNote: A scarecrow is a man-like figure made to scare birds and prevent them from eating the crops. Here Yahweh compares the idols to scarecrows because they are not capable of doing anything. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: What they make with their hands is like scarecrows

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the sound of the raging fire to the sound of a severe storm. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: that will sound like the roar of a storm

contextId.occurrenceNote: "I will scatter them like chaff that is blown away by the wind." Yahweh is saying He will scatter His people throughout the world just as chaff is scattered by the wind. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I will scatter them like chaff that perishes in the desert wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the donkeys panting because they are thirsty by saying that they pant like jackals. Jackals are fiece wild dog which pant a lot. Alternate translation: "they pant in the wind like thirsty jackals" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: they pant in the wind like jackals

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question speaks of the possibility of Yahweh being unconcerned with helping his people as if he were a stranger just travelling though a place unconcerned with those living there. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: why will you be like a stranger in the land, like a foreign wanderer ... just one night

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the possibility of Yahweh being unable to help his people as if he were a confused warrior who was unable to rescue anyone. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "You do nothing to help us, like someone who is astounded or like a warrior who has no power to rescue us." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Why are you like someone who is astounded, or like a warrior who has no power to rescue?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah is compared to the mouth of Yahweh because he will be used to speak Yahweh's message. Alternate translation: "you will speak for me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: you will be like my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares Jeremiah to a wall because the people will not be able to defeat him. Alternate translation: "I will make you strong, like a bronze wall" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like an impenetrable bronze wall to this people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sons and daughters born in the land are compared to dung on the ground to emphasize that they will be disgusting and that no one will bury them. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Jeremiah 8:2](../08/02.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They will be like dung on the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person who trusts in man instead of Yahweh will be like a plant that struggles to survive in an infertile land. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a small bush

contextId.occurrenceNote: The person who trusts in Yahweh will always prosper, just like a tree does when it is planted by a river. It is not affected when there is no rain. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "he will be like a tree that someone has planted by water" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: he will be like a tree planted by water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares his being able to remake Israel as he see fit to the way that the potter is able to remake a lump of clay as he sees fit. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Like clay in a potter's hand—that is how you are in my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jeremiah compares Yahweh helping him and defending him against his enemies to a powerful warrior. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh is with me like a powerful warrior

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "You are as beautiful as Gilead or the summit of Lebanon" or 2) "You give me as much pleasure as Gilead or the summit of Lebanon." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: You are like Gilead, or like the summit of Lebanon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The pain that the king will feel when his enemies defeat him will be as intense as the pain a woman feels in childbirth. Alternate translation: "when you experience pain as intense as the pain of a woman in childbirth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: when the labor pains come upon you, pain like that of a woman in labor

contextId.occurrenceNote: People who are drunk are not able to control themselves. Likewise, Jeremiah has lost control of himself out of fear of Yahweh's punishment. Alternate translation: "I am like a drunk man; I cannot control myself" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I have become like a drunk man, like a man whom wine has overpowered

contextId.occurrenceNote: The danger of their actions is spoken of as if they were about to fall off the slippery edge of a cliff in the dark and injure themselves. Alternate translation: "there actions are unstable and dangerous, like walking on a slippery place in the darkness" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: their way will be like a slippery place in the darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sodom and Gomorrah were cities that were so wicked that God destroyed them with fire from heaven. Alternate translation: "They all became as evil as Sodom ... as wicked as Gomorrah" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: All of them have become like Sodom ... like Gomorrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: The good figs represent those Judean exiles sent to the land of Chaldea. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: just like these good figs

contextId.occurrenceNote: The bodies are compared to dung on the ground to emphasize that they will be disgusting and that no one will bury them. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Jeremiah 16:4](../16/04.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They will be like dung on the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh had destroyed a place of worship at Shiloh, and he was threatening to destroy this place of worship. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: then I will make this house like Shiloh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Rotten figs are useless because they cannot be eaten, and Yahweh sees no use for the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: For I will make them like rotten figs that are too bad to be eaten

contextId.occurrenceNote: A woman about to give birth is in great pain and unable to do anything. The young men are so frightened that their bodies hurt, and they are unable to fight. Alternate translation: "The young men are holding their bellies like a woman giving birth; they all look sick because they are so afraid." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why do I see every young man with his hand on his loins like a woman bearing a child? Why have all their faces become pale?

contextId.occurrenceNote: A shepherd cares for and protects his sheep, and Yahweh is promising to care for and protect the Israelites. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a shepherd keeps his sheep

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means they will be strong and healthy, and they will prosper. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a watered garden

contextId.occurrenceNote: When people train calves, they strike them and otherwise cause them to suffer. Yahweh had caused the people of Israel to suffer. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I have been punished like an untrained calf

contextId.occurrenceNote: No one can count the stars in the sky or the sand on the seashore, and no one will be able to count the descendants of David and Levi who serve Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As the hosts of heaven cannot be counted, and as the sand of the seashores cannot be measured, so I will increase the descendants of David my servant and the Levites who serve before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Taking or destroying everything in Egypt is compared to how a shepherd carefully cleans off his clothes. Alternate translation: "He will take or destroy everything valuable in Egypt just as a shepherd is careful to get every insect off of his clothes" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He will clean out the land of Egypt just as shepherds clean vermin off their clothes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Nile river floods its banks once a year, covering the surrounding area with water. Yahweh compares the kingdom of Egypt to the Nile because the Egyptian people think they are mighty enough to destroy cities in all the lands. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Egypt rises like the Nile

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the nation of Babylon who will be as overwhelming to the nation of Egypt as the these two mountains are to the plains that surround them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: someone will come like Mount Tabor and Mount Carmel by the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares soldiers to "fattened bulls" because the soldiers are well cared for by the Egyptians just as a farmer takes care of a bull and makes it fat. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: soldiers in her midst are like a fattened bull

contextId.occurrenceNote: The inability of the Egyptians to do anything to stop their enemy is spoken of as if they were snakes that can only hiss and crawl away. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Egypt hisses like a snake and crawls away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemies coming with the weapons to destroy the Egyptians is spoken of as if they were woodcutters with axes preparing to cut down a tree. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They are going toward her like woodcutters with axes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people fleeing from their cities into the desert is compared to a bush or shrub that grows in the desert. Alternate translation: "become like a shrub that grows in the wilderness" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-unknown]])
contextId.glQuote: become like a juniper bush in the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile emphasizes the people should leave their cities and live in the rocky cliffs to hide from their enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Become like a dove ... in the rocks

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases compare how a powerful army will descend on Moab and conquer it to the way an eagle swoops down to capture its prey. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: the enemy will come flying like an eagle, spreading out his wings

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase compares the fear that will overwhelm the soldiers of Moab to the fear a woman may feel when she is about to give birth to her child. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: in that day the hearts of Moab's soldiers ... women in birth labor

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that when Yahweh punishes the people of Edom, it will be fierce and unexpected like when a lion attacks sheep. This can be stated in first person. Alternate translation: "When I punish the people of Edom, it will be fierce and unexpected like when a lion comes out of forest and attacks sheep in the pasture" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.glQuote: he will go up like a lion from the forests of the Jordan to the green pasturelands

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that when the enemy army attacks it will be vicious and unexpected. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: someone will attack like an eagle, and swoop down and spread his wings

contextId.occurrenceNote: The water of the sea is always moving and is never still. This is compared to the people who cannot rest because they are so anxious about the bad news they heard. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They become as troubled as the sea, which cannot stay calm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Male goats tend to be more independent than the rest of the flock. Possible meanings are 1) they should be the first to leave Babylon or 2) they should lead the rest of the Israelites away from Babylon. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: be like male goats that leave

contextId.occurrenceNote: The effectiveness of the arrows of the attacking nations are spoken of as if they were soldiers that always accomplish their mission. The idiom "empty-handed" means "without success." Alternate translation: Each of their arrows are like skilled soldiers that always hit their target" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: Their arrows are like a skilled warrior who does not return empty-handed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The joy of the people of Babylon is compared to a calf who runs around joyfully in a pasture. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: you jump around like a calf stamping in its pasture

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Babylon are compared to stallions that are making loud noises because they are excited. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: you neigh like a powerful horse

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) reduce the city to piles of rubble that look like stacks of grain or 2) stack up the plunder from the city like piles of grain. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: pile her up like heaps of grain

contextId.occurrenceNote: The weakness of the Babylonian soldiers is spoken of as if they were women. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: "they will all become as weak as women" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: they will become like women

contextId.occurrenceNote: The loud noise that the soldiers make is compared to the loud noise of the sea. Alternate translation: "The sound that they make is very loud, like the sound of the sea" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Their sound is like the sea roar

contextId.occurrenceNote: The anguish that they feel because the enemy coming to attack them is compared to the anguish that a woman feels when she is about to give birth to a baby. Alternate translation: "like a woman who is about to give birth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a woman giving birth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that when Yahweh punishes the people of Babylon, it will be fierce and unexpected like when a lion attacks sheep. This can be stated in the first person. Alternate translation: "When I punish the people of Babylon, it will be fierce and unexpected like when a lion comes out of mountains and attacks sheep in the pasture" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-123person]])
contextId.glQuote: He goes up like a lion from the heights of the Jordan to the enduring grazing place

contextId.occurrenceNote: The large number of enemy soldiers is spoken of as if they were a mass of locusts invading the city. Alternate translation: "with a large number of soldiers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a swarm of locusts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares a great number of horses to a swarm of locusts. Alternate translation: "bring many horses with soldiers quickly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: bring up horses like swarming locusts

contextId.occurrenceNote: People thresh grain by trampling it on a threshing floor, and Yahweh speaks of people punishing the daughter of Babylon as if they were threshing grain. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: is like a threshing floor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Babylon is compared to a monster. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Like a monster

contextId.occurrenceNote: Lambs and goats do not know before it happens that people are going to slaughter them, and the Babylonians will not know before it happens that Yahweh is going to destroy them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like lambs ... male goats

contextId.occurrenceNote: The waves of the ocean and of flooding rivers make a loud sound, and the enemies will make a very loud sound as they come. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: enemies roar like the waves of many waters

contextId.occurrenceNote: The stone and scroll will disappear in the water, the water will destroy the scroll, and Babylon will no longer look like a city or have buildings for people to live in. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Babylon will sink like this
